Implement screening operations for the facility. Available screening options include, but are not limited to, x-ray scanners, magnetometers, package searches, and physical searches. Post signage to notify potential entrants that screening is a prerequisite for entry into the facility.
Limit visitor access to the facility at a level consistent with onsite safety and security requirements.
Require visitors to sign in and sign out.
Issue badges to visitors and require badges to be displayed at all times at the facility. Collect badges when visits are complete.

vulnerability: The facility has numerous extraneous access points for ingress, or has numerous access points that are unsecured.
description: The facility has numerous extraneous access points for ingress, or has numerous access points that are unsecured.
options_for_consideration: Evaluate the number of unsecured or unnecessary access points available for ingress, and explore ways to limit the number of access points or eliminate extraneous points of entry.

vulnerability: The facility does not exercise its business continuity plan annually.
description: The facility does not exercise its business continuity plan annually.
options_for_consideration: Evaluate the business continuity plan through annual exercises. Ensure exercises are designed to accomplish the following: 1) Identify planning and procedural deficiencies; 2) Test or validate recently changed procedures or plans; 3) Clarify roles and responsibilities; 4) Obtain participant feedback and recommendations for program improvement; 5) Measure improvement compared to performance objectives; 6) Improve coordination between internal and external teams, organizations, and entities; 7) Validate training and education; and 8) Identify additional resources and assess the capabilities of existing resources, including personnel and equipment needed for effective business continuity and recovery.

vulnerability: The facility does not have a CCTV system. CCTV systems support surveillance of activities and events within and around a facility.
description: The facility does not have a CCTV system. CCTV systems support surveillance of activities and events within and around a facility.
options_for_consideration: Explore the feasibility of installing a comprehensive CCTV system onsite. Site-specific factors must be considered when selecting components that comprise a particular CCTV system. For example, the size of the system, in terms of the number of cameras needed, is the minimum number required to view all electronic security system sensor detection fields. In addition, some cameras may require artificial light sources. Finally, performance criteria and physical, environmental, and economic considerations must be factored into the component selection.
Consult Reference Manual to Mitigate Potential Terrorist Attacks Against Buildings (FEMA 426/BIPS 06), available at https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/st/st-bips-06.pdf, for more information.

vulnerability: The facility lacks procedures for handling suspicious packages.
description: The facility lacks procedures for handling suspicious packages.
options_for_consideration: Refer to the FEMA Emergency Management Institute's Independent Study Program training course IS-906: Workplace Security Awareness. This free, 1-hour course provides guidance to individuals and organizations on how to improve security in the workplace and is available at http://training.fema.gov/EMIWeb/IS/IS906.asp.
Develop procedures for handling suspicious packages.
Incorporate procedures on how to handle suspicious packages into initial and annual security training programs.

Implement U.S. Postal Service mail center security procedures to assess, prevent, and respond to threats such as suspicious letters and packages; bomb threats; and chemical, biological, or radiological contamination.
Prominently display informational materials on suspicious package indicators in the mailroom.
Refer to the Ready.gov website for information about suspicious packages and letters, at http://www.ready.gov/explosions.
Ensure bomb threat checklists are accessible at all work stations where inbound calls are received.

Create and use a central repository for all U.S. mail and other deliveries where packages can then be picked up or delivered to addressees in a controlled manner. See U.S. Postal Service guidelines for a mail room so that if anything suspicious does occur, it will minimally impact the overall operation of the site, if at all. Consult the DHS guidance document, Best Practices for Mail Screening and Handling Processes: A Guide for the Public and Private Sectors to inform the development of policies, procedures, and training for recognizing and handling suspicious packages.

Consult the DHS guidance document, Best Practices for Mail Screening and Handling Processes: A Guide for the Public and Private Sectors, available at https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/Mail_Handling_Document_NonFOUO%209-27-2012.pdf, to inform the development of policies, procedures, and training for recognizing and handling suspicious packages.
Train facility or organization volunteers on suspicious-package and IED recognition using local explosivedetection -teams for partnership opportunities.

vulnerability: Background checks are not conducted on contract security personnel.
description: Background checks are not conducted on contract security personnel.
options_for_consideration: Conduct background checks on contract security personnel.
Require security contracting companies to conduct background checks on their personnel who will work at the facility and to make such records available for audit.

vulnerability: The facility does not exchange information through the HSIN portal. Using the HSIN portal for information sharing would enhance the security and resilience posture of the facility.
description: The facility does not exchange information through the HSIN portal. Using the HSIN portal for information sharing would enhance the security and resilience posture of the facility.
options_for_consideration: Consult your local PSA to become a member of the HSIN community. Information about HSIN is also available via the DHS website, at https://www.dhs.gov/homeland-security-information-network-hsin.

vulnerability: The facility has no security team or threat assessment team to identify potential threats or respond to security incidents. The lack of a security team may allow potential threats to go unnoticed and leave the facility without the ability to respond to security incidents.
description: The facility has no security team or threat assessment team to identify potential threats or respond to security incidents. The lack of a security team may allow potential threats to go unnoticed and leave the facility without the ability to respond to security incidents.
options_for_consideration: Establish a security or threat assessment team that can identify potential threats and respond to security incidents at the facility.
Provide the security and threat assessment teams training that include basic security principles, threat indicators, and response to natural and intentional threats.

vulnerability: The security force does not receive training on procedures in the event of a natural disaster.
description: The security force does not receive training on procedures in the event of a natural disaster.
options_for_consideration: Ensure the security force receives training on emergency response procedures for regional natural disasters
Review the list of FEMA training materials available at http://www.training.fema.gov.

vulnerability: The facility has limited or no access control policies/procedures for contractors/vendors.
description: The facility has limited or no access control policies/procedures for contractors/vendors.
options_for_consideration: Install access control systems and/or implement access control procedures designed to permit only authorized access, detect and prevent contraband from being brought into the facility, and provide information to security personnel to facilitate the appropriate assessment and response. Effective access control can be established through the integrated use of guards, locks, credentials, and/or screening equipment (e.g., x-ray scanners, magnetometers).
Maintain a list of regular contractors/vendors.

Post security guards at entrances to facilitate access control procedures such as credential checks and searches. If this is not possible, integrate CCTV or other surveillance equipment to facilitate remote monitoring of access points.

Implement screening operations for the facility. Available screening options include, but are not limited to, x-ray scanners, magnetometers, package searches, and physical searches. Post signage to notify potential entrants that screening is a prerequisite for entry into the facility.
Limit contractor/vendor access to the facility at a level consistent with onsite safety and security requirements.
Require contractors/vendors to sign in and sign out.
Issue badges to contractors/vendors and require badges to be displayed at all times at the facility. Collect badges when visits are complete.
Escort contractors/vendors as necessary, either at all times or only in sensitive/critical areas.

vulnerability: Main entrance doors are not locked, or existing locks are ineffective.
description: Main entrance doors are not locked, or existing locks are ineffective.
options_for_consideration: Ensure effective locking mechanisms exist on doors. Keep doors locked when not actively monitored and in use.
